phosphorus-nickel-tungsten/alumina hydrotreating catalysts P. Lopez Agudob a Institute of Catalysis, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 1113 Sofia, Bulgaria b C.S.LC., lnstituto de Catalisis y Petroleoquimica, Campus Universidad Autonoma, Cantoblanco, 28 049 Madrid, Spain Received 11 June 1996; received in revised form 1 October 1996; accepted 2 November 1996 Abstract Two series of phosphorus containing Ni-W/AI203 catalysts were prepared by different preparation methods and varying phosphorus content from 0 to 7.6 wt.% P205. The influence of the phosphorus concentration and the preparation procedure on the structure and the dispersion of the compounds formed in the oxide form of the catalysts was studied. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), infrared spectroscopy (IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used for the characterization of the catalysts. It was demonstrated that introduction of phosphorus in NiW/AI203 catalysts impedes the formation of NiAI204 and increases the amount of Ni2+(Oh) ions in the oxide form of the samples. This effect of phosphorus is better expressed when phosphorus is first introduced to alumina, followed by co-impregnation with nickel and tungsten. Surface AIPO4 is formed in the phosphorus containing samples irrespective of the preparation procedure. Phosphorus is distributed as a monolayer up to concentrations of 1.3 P at/nm2 in both series of catalysts. It was also found that the increased phosphorus content in the samples leads to an increased degree of polymerization of the tungsten species via W-O-W bonds. The presence of phosphorus changes the dispersion of the active components. Evaluation of the average particle size of tungsten species shows that it increases from 10 ]~ for the phosphorus free sample up to 20-25 ,~ for the samples with high phosphorus content. The relationship between the structure of the phosphorus promoted NiW/AI203 catalysts and their hydrodesulfurization activity is discussed. ~, 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Introduction Introduction of phosphorus in promoted and non- promoted molybdenum-based hydrotreating catalysts was shown to influence their hydrodesulfurization (HDS), hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) and hydrogena- tion (HYD) activity, depending on phosphorus con- 0926-860X/97/$17.00 (~ 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Different conclusions regarding the promoting role of phos- phorus on the HDS activity were suggested: the for- mation of the inactive nickel aluminate phase impeded by the phosphorus interaction with the alumina sup- port [2]; improved dispersion of the active phases [3,5,7]; increased stacking of MoS2 and change in the morphology of the active species [4,6,9]; direct participation of phosphorus in the active phase [8,10]. In some cases promoting effect of phosphorus on the HDS activity of molybdenum-based alumina-sup- ported catalysts was observed ]3,4,7], while practi- cally no effect of phosphorus or even a negative effect was found in other studies [6,9]. It has been also suggested that phosphorus has a direct role in the HDN reaction due to the formation of new active sites associated with the acidic surface A1PO4 species [6] and significant promoting effect of phosphorus on the activity of NiMo/A1203 in HDN of quinoline [6,11], aniline [11] and pyridine [8] was observed. In other studies, a negative effect of phosphorus on the HDN of quinoline [9] and piperidine and pyridine [11] has been found and assigned to differences in the reaction pathway corresponding to the molecule used as a model compound for the HDN reaction [11]. Contrary to molybdenum-based catalysts [ [1-12], and references therein] the effect of the phosphorus concentration on the HDS, HDN and HYD activity of tungsten-based alumina-supported catalysts has been analyzed in a very limited number of studies [ 13-16]. Investigation of the structure and activity of co- impregnated P-W/A1203 catalysts showed that both HDS and HDN activities were notably enhanced by increasing the phosphorus content [14]. A study of a series of co-impregnated P-Ni-W/A1203 catalysts with low tungsten content showed that phosphorus has a promoting effect on the activity of naphthalene HYD [ 16]. The promoting effect of phosphorus on the HDS and HYD activity of Ni-W/A1203 catalysts was reported recently, also depending on the preparation method-the step impregnated (phosphorus first) cata- lysts manifested higher activity than the co-impreg- nated ones [15]. The driving force for the interest in Ni-W/A1203 catalysts is also due to their potential application for upgrading coal-derived liquids as they show much higher HDN and HYD activities compared to Ni- Mo/A1203 and Co-Mo/A1203 catalysts [17]. Having in mind the similarities in the structure of Mo- and W-based catalysts and the extended knowledge for the promoting effect of phosphorus on HDS, HDN and HYD activity for Mo-based catalysts, it was justifiable to investigate systematically the influence of the phosphorus concentration and of the preparation method on the structure of Ni-W/A1203 system. The structure of the oxide and sulfided forms of Ni-W/AI203 catalysts has been analyzed by different experimental techniques and conclusions have been made about the relationship between the composition, preparation conditions, sulfidation procedure and the structure and activity of these catalysts in different reactions [ 18-27]. In a previous paper on the structure of the oxide form of a series of phosphorus-containing NiW/A1203 samples with low tungsten concentration, prepared by co-impregnation, we reported that the distribution of both Ni and W is inhomogeneous, strongly influenced by the presence of phosphorus, and that the increase of phosphorus concentration stimulates the formation of a NiWO4 phase [13], The HDS activity of these samples was not influenced by the presence of phosphorus except for the sample with the highest phosphorus content, for which the activity decreases [28]. This result suggested that promoting effect of phosphorus on HDS can not be achieved in catalysts where it stimulates formation of species with poor dispersion and not sulfidable at the conventionally used temperatures of sulfidation (crystalline NiWO4, for example). It has been reported in several papers on phosphorus containing Mo/A1203 [4,29] and Co(Ni)-Mo/A1203 [5,7] catalysts that the preparation method (especially the sequence of the introduction of phosphorus, simul- taneously or by step impregnation) is important for the structure and the activity of the samples. It has been suggested recently for P-Mo/A1203 catalysts that uni- form Mo dispersion can be achieved either by co- impregnation with phosphorus at low pH or by sequential (after phosphorus) impregnation at pH higher than the isoelectric point of the support [30]. However, when it comes to more complicated Ni- promoted catalysts, the co-impregnation of phos- phorus, nickel and tungsten at pH=l resulted in catalysts with poor dispersion of the active compo- nents and formation of separate crystalline phases - NiO, WO3 [13]. Therefore, the effect of the prepara- P. The aim of the present paper is to examine both the effect of the method of preparation and of the phos- phorus concentration on the dispersion of nickel and tungsten and on the type of structures formed in the oxide form of two series of phosphorus-containing NiW/A1203 catalysts. The samples were studied by UV-VIS diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), infrared spectroscopy (IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The relation between the struc- ture of the oxide form and the catalytic activity of these catalysts in HDS of thiophene is also discussed. 2. Experimental 2. I. Preparation and composition of the samples The samples were obtained by multiple step impregnation according to moisture capacity of the ~/-A1203 support, precalcined at 873 K (specific sur- face area 266 m2g 1, pore volume 0.62 cm3g-1 and average pore radius of 4.6 nm). Details on the alumina support preparation are given elsewhere [3]. The term 'multiple step impregnation' means that the total amount of the W, Ni and P content (for the co- impregnated series) was introduced by four impreg- nation steps, in each of them with solution equal to the moisture capacity of the support, followed by inter- mediate drying of the catalysts at 373 K. The con- centration of (NH4)6 H2W12040 and Ni(NO3)~ in the impregnation solution was 104.4 g/1 and 47.75 g/l respectively. In the case of step-impregnated catalysts the whole amount of phosphorus was introduced at once in the first impregnation step, followed by drying and calcination, and by four co-impregnation steps with W and Ni. The details of the preparation proce- dures were as follows: l. W/AI203 and NiW/AI203 samples: prepared by four impregnation steps with (NH4)6 H2WIzO4o or respectively (NH4)6 H2WI2040 and Ni(NO3)2.6 H20 (co-impregnated) solutions. The samples were dried after each impregnation step at 373 K for 1 h and finally calcined at 823 K for 2 h. The impregna- tion solution was adjusted to pH 4.0 by HNO3. 2. NiWP(x)/A1203 samples: prepared by four co- impregnation steps with solutions of (NH4)6 H2WI2040, Ni(NO3)2.6 H20 and H3PO4. After each impregnation step the samples were dried at 373 K for l h and finally calcined at 823 K for 2 h. The impregnation solution was adjusted to pH 4.0 by ammonia solution. 3. NiW-P(x)/AI203 samples: prepared by initial impregnation of the support with H3PO4 solution at pH 2.0. Then the samples were dried at 373 K for 1 h and calcined at 823 K for 2 h. Catalysts characterization The specific surface area of the samples was mea- sured by the BET method (nitrogen adsorption at 77 K) on an ASAP 2000 apparatus (Micromeritics). XRD diffraction patterns were obtained on a Phillips diffractometer using nickel-filtered CUK~ radiation. Diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded on a Beckman 5270 UV-VIS-NIR spectrometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory with an integrating sphere. Spectra were recorded in the 250 -2200 nm range using barium sulfate as refer- ence. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicko- let ZDX FTIR spectrometer using potassium bromide pellets. Compensation of alumina absorption was used in the 1000-400cm-1 range by subtraction of a normalized spectrum of an equivalent amount of carrier from the spectra of the samples. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on an ESCALAB-MKII (VG Scientific) spectrometer, working in AE = constant mode at a pass energy of 50 eV, using an aluminium anode (A1K,~ 1486.7 eV, 250 W). The residual pressure in the ana- lysis chamber was 6.10-8 tort (1 torr =133.3 Pa). The samples were pressed into pellets in metal holders and all conditions of samples preparation, recording of the spectra and data processing were identical for all samples. The peak positions are relative to the binding energy of AI 2p =74.5 eV. The experimental relative intensities used in comparison to the theoretically cal- culated ones are evaluated after normalization of the peak areas for the number of scans, time per channel, scan width and number of channels. The peak area of Ni 2p3/2 includes the area of the satellite peak. 2.3. HDS activity test The HDS activity of the samples was determined in a glass flow tube reactor at a temperature of 623 K and atmospheric pressure using thiophene as model com- pound. The catalysts samples (0.5 g, particle size 0.2- 0.4 mm) were presulfided in situ with a flow of H2S/H2 (1 : 10) mixture for 2 h at 623 K. Catalytic activity measurements were performed using a reaction mix- ture of H2/thiophene gas ratio of 34 : 1. The analysis of the reaction products was made using a gas chro- matograph connected to the reactor via a six-way valve. Samples were taken after reaching a steady state composition of the mixture at the reactor outlet. The reaction products detected for all catalysts were butane, 1-butene, and cis/trans-2-butenes plus H2S and unreacted thiophene. The hydrodesulfurization activity of the catalysts was expressed as thiophene conversion in mol %. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Two series of phosphorus containing NiW/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by different preparation methods and varying phosphorus content from 0 to 7.6 wt.% P2O5. The influence of the phosphorus concentration and the preparation procedure on the structure and the dispersion of the compounds formed in the oxide form of the catalysts was studied. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), infrared spectroscopy (IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used for the characterization of the catalysts. It was demonstrated that introduction of phosphorus in NiW/Al2O3 catalysts impedes the formation of NiAl2O4 and increases the amount of Ni2+(Oh) ions in the oxide form of the samples. This effect of phosphorus is better expressed when phosphorus is first introduced to alumina, followed by co-impregnation with nickel and tungsten. Surface AlPO4 is formed in the phosphorus containing samples irrespective of the preparation procedure. Phosphorus is distributed as a monolayer up to concentrations of 1.3 P at/nm2 in both series of catalysts. It was also found that the increased phosphorus content in the samples leads to an increased degree of polymerization of the tungsten species via WOW bonds. The presence of phosphorus changes the dispersion of the active components. Evaluation of the average particle size of tungsten species shows that it increases from 10Åfor the phosphorus free sample up to 20–25Åfor the samples with high phosphorus content. The relationship between the structure of the phosphorus promoted NiW/Al2O3 catalysts and their hydrodesulfurization activity is discussed. coredata.dc:description: Two series of phosphorus containing NiW/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by different preparation methods and varying phosphorus content from 0 to 7.6 wt.% P2O5. The influence of the phosphorus concentration and the preparation procedure on the structure and the dispersion of the compounds formed in the oxide form of the catalysts was studied. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), infrared spectroscopy (IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used for the characterization of the catalysts. It was demonstrated that introduction of phosphorus in NiW/Al2O3 catalysts impedes the formation of NiAl2O4 and increases the amount of Ni2+(Oh) ions in the oxide form of the samples. This effect of phosphorus is better expressed when phosphorus is first introduced to alumina, followed by co-impregnation with nickel and tungsten. Surface AlPO4 is formed in the phosphorus containing samples irrespective of the preparation procedure. Phosphorus is distributed as a monolayer up to concentrations of 1.3 P at/nm2 in both series of catalysts. It was also found that the increased phosphorus content in the samples leads to an increased degree of polymerization of the tungsten species via WOW bonds. The presence of phosphorus changes the dispersion of the active components. Evaluation of the average particle size of tungsten species shows that it increases from 10Åfor the phosphorus free sample up to 20–25Åfor the samples with high phosphorus content. The relationship between the structure of the phosphorus promoted NiW/Al2O3 catalysts and their hydrodesulfurization activity is discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of phosphorus concentration and method of preparation on the structure of the oxide form of phosphorus-nickel-tungsten/alumina hydrotreating catalysts
